newsitem.title: USA: Dec U.S. NAPM rise points to healthy 1997 momentum.
newsitem.headline: Dec U.S. NAPM rise points to healthy 1997 momentum.

text.p: U.S. manufacturing accelerated strongly last month, suggesting healthy economic expansion heading into 1997, analysts said after reviewing a key factory-sector survey.
The National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) on Thursday said its index of manufacturing activity rose to 54.0 in December from 52.7 in November.
Economists had expected the index would decline to 51.5, according to a Reuters poll last Friday.

"If (the NAPM index) were to continue at this level ... you would have (Gross Domestic Product) growth in the 3.0 to 3.5 percent range," said Matthew Alexy, chief bond market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Norbert Ore, the new chairman of the NAPM's Business Survey Committee, concurred.
"By the data that we track, 54.0 would be equal to a 3.5-percent (growth rate), which would be a pretty strong economy," Ore said in a teleconference following release of the report.
The jump in the NAPM index triggered bond-market selling in which the price of the bellwether 30-year bond slid more than a full point. Stocks plummeted as well.
Individual components of the report appeared more troubling than the headline number, analysts said.
The prices paid index, in particular, climbed to 51.5 from 45.9, prompting some concern about inflation and questions about Federal Reserve monetary policy.
Michelle Colley Laughlin, chief Treasuries strategist at Prudential Securities Inc, said the price index reading would prompt fears the Fed would hike interest rates near term.
"It's raising concerns over a possible Fed tightening in the first quarter," she said.
Any concern might be premature, however, Laughlin added.
"I think it's a temporary increase tied to the recent energy price gains," she said.
Supplier deliveries inched upward last month, to 51.6 from 51.5, suggesting there is no major bottleneck that might trigger a longer-term price run-up, Laughlin said.
Kurt Karl, chief economist of WEFA Group's U.S. forecasting center, said although the NAPM index might not signal an imminent rate hike, it erases hopes for an easing.
"We had thought the Fed would perhaps lower interest rates this year, and we just decided this morning that's quite unlikely," Karl said. "We'll have no change in Fed interest rates this year."
On the flip side, Karl said, NAPM at 54.0 is not outrageously strong.
"Fifty-four is not a terribly strong purchasing managers' number," he said. "It is growing and it is slightly above average."
